Award.AwardTitle: Standard Research Grant: Public Interpretations of and Responses to Scientific Disputes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Disputes are usually deemed fruitful to scientific process, but can confuse publics who learn about and attend to such disputes as to "the truth," regardless of contenders' relative numbers or persuasive evidence, so that disagreements among experts may individually or collectively undermine lay trust in and support for science and scientists. Potential outcomes may include misconstruing the true nature of a field's uncertainties, ignoring expert advice on protecting oneself, or reducing support for use of science in polic ymaking or education. This research systematically assesses across varied topics how laypeople interpret, process, and are affected by scientific disputes: 1) How do lay people interpret disagreements among scientists in terms of dispute origins and cues to which of the contending sides is most credible?; 2) What beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors about the disputed topic or science stem from these lay interpretations?; and 3) How malleable are such interpretations and responses to interventions (e.g., education on scientific process)? This project advances theory in public understanding of science, including conditions that alter public interpretations of and responses to expert disputes; helps scientists tailor their messages to remove ambiguities, reduce errors among observers, and enhance public discourse on science and science-based policy; and makes a novel and substantial contribution to our understanding of the place of science in contemporary society.

This research shows public samples scenarios involving two-sided mass disputes on topics varying in public salience, impacts, and familiarity, such as the nature of dark matter, desirable dietary salt intake, or nanotechnology. Focus groups probe people's reactions to sample scenarios, and their rationales for how they determine answers to such questions as which side is "correct," and why experts might disagree. An experiment then probes how people's responses (e.g., trust, intentions to comply with expert advice, support for federal funding of science) vary according to whether experts are split 50-50, are 99% in support of one side, or somewhere in between, to determine if different proportions drive shifts from one response to another. A survey probes the relative role of knowledge, values, self-interest, history, and vote-counting (i.e., the proportion of support for a given side in the dispute) as factors in lay beliefs about why scientific disputes occur (e.g., self-interest, incompetence, inherent complexity of the topic), cues to disputants' credibility (e.g., perceived uncertainty of the field, credentials, salient value similarity, self-interest), and lay responses to disputes among scientists. A subsequent experiment manipulates several of these factors to further test the causal relationship between dispute attributes and public responses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Disagreement among scientists about new answers is common, which helps them eventually agree more about how the world works. While usually the public is unaware of these disputes, sometimes citizens become aware and even want to decide which side is more likely to be correct. Some disputes may involve issues with personal implications--should I cut back on my kids' salt intake? does using marijuana have more benefits than risks?--while other debates simply arouse curiosity. Public engagement with scientists' disagreements also might affect public support for science, if (for example) citizens decide that such disputes indicate that scientists cannot be trusted or we should reduce government funding for research.

This project explored how laypeople--people who are not scientists--interpret and respond to disagreements among two large groups of scientists, using actual disputes as examples. Compared to disputes between individual scientists, where a layperson might decide one expert is more honest or seems more competent, evaluating large-group disputes provides both extra ways to judge the two positions (for example, which side is supported by more scientists?) and extra challenges (for example, how does a non-scientist find out which side has the majority or has better evidence?). Focus groups, a survey, and several experiments using U.S. respondents helped answer project questions.

Laypeople saw three reasons for why scientists disagree: incompetence, bias, and complexity of the topic. These reasons differed little by topic (complexity chosen less often for a dispute over marijuana harms and benefits, interests/values less often over what invisible "dark matter" makes up most of the universe) or person (more knowledge of scientific facts reduced choice of complexity; liberal ideology increased scientists' credibility, reducing choice of interests/values). Laypeople did not see using different scientific methods (due to different traditions or options within a specific scientific field, or from different disciplines) as different from issues of competence, or unconscious differences in values as different from conscious bias.

When asked, laypeople rated research quality (such as having more recent, better-measured information, or independently replicating results across multiple studies), experience, and credentials (e.g., degrees, awards) as the most reliable cues to which side in the dispute was correct, while self-interest (ability to gain money or prestige for the scientist or his/her employer) and demographics (e.g., whether the scientist was American) were deemed poor cues. Experiments tended to find that if Position B in the dispute had the majority vote, more experience, or better replication, citizens were more likely to favor Position B as more likely correct than Position A. Factors such as topic familiarity or involvement, mistrust of science, belief that science finds the truth (positivism), and knowledge of scientific reasoning reduced cue effects overall. 

People in focus groups emphasized self-interest ("follow the money!" regarding who employs or funds scientists), but the survey and experiments found self-interest of little perceived or actual influence on which side in a dispute is correct. Another experiment explored how people defined scientists' motivations and relations with their employers (federal government agencies, national corporations, nonprofit advocacy groups, universities). Overall citizens saw scientists' motivations as more intrinsic (doing good science, enjoying a challenge, helping society or others) than extrinsic (gaining money or fame, helping employer), although they also wanted motivations even more intrinsic. The few differences included agencies perceived to share motivations less than the other employers, corporations thought more able to change scientists' work than advocacy groups, and for shared interests and values the four institutions differed significantly, from low to high as agency, corporation, advocacy group, and university. The most consistent predictors of these views were belief in scientific positivism, knowledge of basic science facts, and age; belief that scientists had intrinsic motivations also predicted belief in shared motivations. Conservative political ideology and credibility of scientists had relatively little effect. These findings suggest scientific authority in the U.S. is not immediately threatened by public beliefs that employers are skewing their scientific employees' work.

These findings advance scientific knowledge by providing some of the first evidence on how people respond to disputes among masses of scientists, in terms of their interpretations of why these occur, their perceptions of potential cues' reliability and how they are affected by cues' availability, and how disputes affect their views of scientists and science. Only a few experiments about how people interpret disputes between individual scientists, some experiments on how people react to scientists' consensus, and studies of particular disputes complement this project's output.

These findings have potential practical significance in several ways. Science communicators can improve how they try to educate citizens about the strengths and weaknesses of both different reasons for scientific disputes, and of cues about the relative validity of disputants' positions. Communicators, scientists and media-runners could explore how to make the more reliable cues more available to interested members of the public.
